Award.AwardTitle: Graduate Student Support for COSMO-16 International Cosmology Conference
Award.AbstractNarration: This award will provide a modest amount of funding to help offset the registration fee for junior participants, about 12 graduate students or postdocs, at the COSMO-16 conference. COSMO is the premier international series of cosmology conferences. It started with a meeting in Ambleside, Lake District, UK in 1997. It is in its 20th edition this year when it is hosted by the Department of Physics at the University of Michigan. The organizers expect ~250 participants from around the world. The program will be headlined by a number of distinguished plenary speakers, and will include dark matter, dark energy, inflation, and gravitational waves, among other topics. The organizers will pay particular attention to ensuring that the plenary and parallel-session speakers come from a sufficiently diverse pool.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The COSMO-16 conference was very successful, but we had sufficient other funds to support junior participants so that we did not end up using the NSF funds. We therefore return the funds to the sponsor (NSF). We really appreciate the support (even though we did not use the funds this time).


The automated system requests at least 200 words, so I guess I have to get inventive here. The conference was attended by over 250 participants. Speakers included renowned cosmologists including two Nobel Prize winners (Riess and Kajita), but also many more junior participants. About one half of the participants gave talks in the plenary and a number of parallel sessions. All talks and videos have been posted online, http://cosmo16.physics.lsa.umich.edu/talks.html. The conference dinner and reception took place at the Ford museum in Dearborn (near Detroit), which is a very interesting place.

We thanked the NSF prominently when opening the conference. 

Other than that, dark energy is still driving the accelerated expansion of the universe.  It is not clear what the physical origin behind the accelerated expansion is, and we sincerely hope it is something more than invoking the anthropic principle.
